topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0: Deploying a vApp for DCN/ESX Integration (VRSvApp)

p.i: Return to installing the non-KVM region for the memphis or sacramento template.

body.p: This document describes how to install the HP Distributed Cloud Networking (DCN) vSphere Solution required to properly integrate the HPE Distributed Cloud Networking and VMWare ESX components.

The HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade in the KVM + ESX Deployment requires a VMware vApp, called the VRSvApp, to integrate ESX and HPE DCN. One VRSvApp is required for each ESX host. There is a 1-to-1 mapping between each VRSvApp and its ESX host. The VRSvApp installation package is contained in the packages you downloaded in the Prerequisites.

The DCN vSphere Solution addresses this integration. The installation involves deploying a stand-alone VM, installing the new vCenter Integration Node (called the vCenter Deployment Toolbox). The VRSvApp can be deployed automatically on each ESX node in a cluster.

After installing the vCenter Integration Node VM and vCenter Deployment Toolbox, you can access the toolbox by pointing a browser to https://<VSD_IP>:8443/vcenter/. Only the CSPRoot user can log into the vCenter deployment toolbox.
The VRSvApp installation involves the following tasks:

ul.li: Create a VM for the vCenter Integration Node
Create a VM for HTTP and DHCP services
Configuring ESX details into VRSvApp Deployer
Configuring the Nuage VRS Agent Manager in vCenter Client and deploy VRSvApp

section.title: Pre-requisites:
section.p: Before installing the VRSvApp, make sure the following conditions are met:

ul.li: The system hosting the vCenter Integration Node as one NIC in the Management network.
The DHCP server should have one network interface in the DVRS Datapath network (TUL Network)
The DHCP server requires at least 20 TUL IP addresses for the DHCP scope.

body.section:
Import Templates to Create Required VMs
Two VMs are required for the DCN vSphere Solution. You can use ESX vCenter client to import template files to create these VMs. You should have downloaded these template files during the prerequisites.
For instructions on how to import OVA files, refer to the ESX documentation.To deploy the vCenter Integration Node VM:
Launch the vCenter client, at https://<vcenter IP>:9443/vsphere-client.
Import the VSD-3.2.4_134-hp.ova file into vCenter server. Importing the OVA file creates the vCenter Integration Node VM. During the installation, you will select a network for the VM. Select the DVS Datapath (TUL) network. Select the
Import the itoolbox1.ova template file.
You should have downloaded this file during the prerequisites. Importing the OVA file creates the HTTP\DHCP VM. During the installation, you will select a network for the VM. Select the DVS Datapath (TUL) network.
For instructions, refer to the ESX documentation.

Configure the vCenter Integration Node (Deployment Toolbox)The HPE DCN vSphere Solution requires that you install a dedicated virtual machine on an ESX server. This VM is called the vCenter Integration Node, and includes the vCenter Deployment Toolbox. You created the vCenter Integration Node when you imported the OVA file above.
The vCenter Integration Node VM requires a Virtualized Services Directory (VSD) instance. The instance does not require a VSD license and does not offer VSD functionality.
To deploy the vCenter Integration Node VM:
Login to the vCenter Integration Node VM using username root and password Alcateldc. You assigned the IP address when importing the OVA template file.
Important: After logging in with the default password, make sure you change the password for the root user.
Edit the /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0 file to configure a static IP address for the vCenter Integration Node VM, using the TUL IP.
For exampleBOOTPROTO=”static” IPADDR=10.20.5.21 NETMASK=255.255.255.0 GATEWAY=10.20.5.1
After NTP is properly synchronized, execute the following command to install VSD:/opt/vsd/install.sh

section.title: Configure the HTTP\DHCP VM for the vCenter Integration Node
section.p: The HPE DCN vSphere Solution requires that you install a dedicated virtual machine on an ESX server for HTTP\DCHP services. You created the HTTP\DHCP VM when you imported the OVA file above.
Perform the following step create a VM for HTTP and DHCP services.

ol.li:
In the vCenter client, import the itoolbox1.ovatemplate file.
You should have downloaded this file during the prerequisites. Importing the OVA file creates the HTTP\DHCP VM.
For instructions, refer to the ESX documentation.

Login to the HTTP\DHCP VM using username root and password cghelion. You assigned the IP address when importing the OVA template file.
Important: After logging in with the default password, make sure you change the password for the root user.

Edit the /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0 file to configure a static IP address. For the vCenter Integration Node VM, use the HPE OpenStack Carrier Grade TUL IP.
For exampleBOOTPROTO=”static” IPADDR=10.20.5.21 NETMASK=255.255.255.0 GATEWAY=10.20.5.1
Restart the Networking service using the following command: service network restart
Restart the DHCP service:service dhcpd restart
Copy the VRSvApp template files, VRS_3.2.4-135_10062015.ovf and VRS_3.2.4-135_10062015-disk1.vmdk to the DocumentRoot (/var/www/html is the default location).
Check Apache server and make sure it’s running and restart if needed:Service httpd restart

body.section:
Installing the vCenter Deployment ToolboxThe vCenter Deployment Toolbox is bundled as a metadata plug-in.
To install and configure the metadata plugin:
Log into the vCenter Integration Node VM using SSH. The default username is root and password is Alcateldc.
Execute the following command to stop the JBoss application server on the vCenter Integration Node VM: monit stop jboss
Edit the /opt/vsd/jboss/standalone/configuration/metadataplugin.properties file. Enter vCenter properties the in the fields, as follows:vc.host=x.x.x.x //: This is the vCenter IP address: vc.http.proxy.port = 80 //: This is the default port. Do not change. vc.https.proxy.port = 443 //: This is the default port. Do not change. vc.user = root //: vCenter username vc.password =vmware //: vCenter password vsd.api.url=https://<vsd_ip>:8443/nuage/api/v3_2
Start the JBoss application server using the following command::monit start jboss
The monit metadata plugin is automatically deployed and installed. The plugin will be listed as registered in vCenter.

section.title: Configure the Deployment Toolbox
section.p: You must perform the following tasks.
You must provide the VMWare topology configuration to the Deployment Toolbox. This includes the following:

ul.li: Each ESX hypervisor in the cluster(s)
Each HPE DCN cluster(s) in data center(s)

section.p: The vCenter configuration requires the following:
The data center and cluster configurations require matching the names of the vCenter configuration objects on vCenter.

ol.li: Log into the vCenter Deployment Toolbox using https://<VSD_IP>:8443/vcenter/ to configure these settings. The default credentials are csproot/csproot.

Create a new vCenter in the VRS Deployer using your ESX vCenter details. Provide a name, description, your vCenter IP, vCenter user, vCenter password, and path to the VRS_3.2.4-135_10062015.ovf file.
The template must be available over an HTTP server, and must allow connection from vCenter and from the Nuage-enabled hypervisors.
Add the Data Center to that vCenter you created:

Add hosts to the cluster you created. Provide a name, description, the ESX Host IP, vCenter user, vCenter password, select the Management, Data amd VM Network names. Select DVRS Datapath for last input
After adding all the hosts vCenter appears similar to the following:

Create a default profile.
The vCenter Deployment Toolbox offers the option of setting up a default vApp profile for all the VRS VM Agents. The profile is used for all default parameters, which generally remain the same across all your agents. The configuration on the default profile includes all the VRS vApp nodes, except the ones that are obviously different for each VRS-VM agent (such as the IP address).
Click the cylinder icon and add the Data (TUL) and Management (CLM) Network. The VSC Controllers are the active/stand-by VSC TUL IPs.
Assign CLM IP and TUL IP for each of hosts in ESX Cluster in the VRS Deployer UI.

section.p: Each level of the topology can be overridden in order to provide different parameters at a more granular level. If a parameter is configured on the level of the default profile, on the cluster level and also on the ESXi level, then only the ESXi-level parameter will be used.

p.b: Enabling the agent settings on each hypervisor

section.p: Each VM that needs to be configured with the Nuage VRS-VM Agent needs to be configured with generic bootstrapping agent settings.

To configure these settings:
Launch the ESX vCenter Web Client, at https://<vcenter IP>:9443/. The IP address is the CLM IP of your vCenter.
Select Hosts and Clusters.
Click Manage, then Settings, then Agent VM Settings.
Click the Edit button
Configure the Datastore and Bootstrap Network settings.
Edit the Agent VM settings and select the desired datastore and VSD-PXE for your VRS vApp.
The Bootstrap Network is the network on which the vCenter Integration Node VM issues DHCP requests and issues requests to the vCenter integration node in order to receive all its parameters.

section.title: Adding the Cluster to the Agency
section.p: After adding the vCenter topology to the vCenter Deployment Toolbox, configure the cluster on vCenter for Agent use.
Note: Make sure that the cluster and hypervisor profiles are properly configured on the vCenter Deployment Toolbox before adding the cluster to the Agency.
Perform the following steps using the vSphere web client:

ol.li: In the vSphere web client, from the Home tab, navigate to vCenter Solutions Manager as shown below:
Click the vCenter Solutions Manager to see a list of extensions, including NuageVRS Agent Manager, as shown below:

Click the Nuage VRS Agent Manager and navigate to the Solutions tab.
If a warning about a certificate issue appears, navigate to https://<vcenter_IP>:8443/EamPlugin-1.6.0/. Confirm the security exception and add the certificate. A message indicating that EAM is up and running appears, and you can continue with the next step.

Add the Nuage cluster:
Select vCenter Solutions Manager and go to the Nuage VRS Agent Manager.
Add the cluster managed by Nuage to the right hand side.
Click Update Configuration. The Agent VMs will be deployed on that cluster.
This action triggers the deploy of VRSvApps for each of the ESXi hosts:
Click the Manage tab.
Click the Actions drop-down list and select Enable Optimized Deployment.
(Optional) To remove the cluster, select the cluster and click first Remove, then Update Configuration.
